importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe of the heist (09:30–09:38) is critical as it outlines the duration of the robbery, the timing of the entry and exit, and the window during which the suspects operated with minimal resistance.

keyTakeAways: The Louvre Museum in Paris was robbed in broad daylight, with thieves using power tools to break into the Gallery of Apollo.

Four suspects used a vehicle-mounted mechanical lift and power tools to cut through a window and enter the museum, threatening guards before stealing eight valuable 19th-century royal jewellery items.
The thieves escaped on two scooters and were reportedly experienced, possibly operating under criminal orders.
One in three rooms in the raided area lacked CCTV, which significantly compromised security and allowed the heist to go undetected for four minutes.
Empress Eugénie's crown was found damaged, suggesting it was dropped during the escape.
Experts believe the stolen items will be broken up and sold in parts to conceal the crime.
The theft has sparked political outrage in France, with President Emmanuel Macron calling it an 'attack on our history' and other leaders calling it a 'humiliation' or 'wound to the French soul'.
The Louvre is still closed, and no reopening date has been announced.
This incident follows a pattern of recent museum thefts in France, including the 2024 Cognacq-Jay and Hieron Museum heists.
The Louvre had previously sought government funding for renovation and security upgrades as part of the New Renaissance project.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In a brazen daylight heist on October 20, 2025, four suspects broke into the Louvre Museum in Paris using power tools and a mechanical lift to gain access to the Gallery of Apollo. After entering at 09:30 and threatening guards, they stole eight valuable 19th-century royal jewellery items—including Empress Eugénie’s crown—before escaping on two scooters by 09:38. The heist occurred in a section with no CCTV in one in three rooms, and despite the museum’s wider alarms sounding, the localised alarm was reportedly broken. French officials, including Culture Minister Rachida Dati and Interior Minister Laurent Nuñez, condemned the incident as a serious blow to national heritage. Experts believe the stolen items will be broken and sold in parts to conceal the crime. The theft has triggered political outrage, with President Emmanuel Macron and other leaders calling it an attack on France’s cultural identity. This incident follows a pattern of recent museum thefts in France, including those at the Cognacq-Jay and Hieron Museums. The Louvre remains closed, and investigators are reviewing CCTV footage and searching for the suspects. The event underscores the need for improved security measures, especially given the Louvre’s previous calls for renovation under the New Renaissance project.
